title: Traps sent to catch stink bug, amid fears it will travel to UK and decimate berry crops
text:
Traps have been set for an Asian stink bug amid fears it has come to the UK and could decimate our fruit crops.

Scientists across the UK are monitoring for signs of the Brown Marmorated Stink Bug, which hitch hiked to the United States in the 1990s and has also spread across Europe.

It has caused significant crop damage in every country in which it has landed, usually by hitching a lift on crates of products imported to the country.

The bug is identifiable through its unique combination of alternating light bands on its antennae and dark bands on the side of its abdomen.

Researchers from Scotland’s Rural College (SRUC), the James Hutton Institute and Science & Advice for Scottish Agriculture (SASA), have set sex pheromone traps near soft fruit fields and Edinburgh Airport to see if the bug has arrived.

The creature appears on the UK Plant Health Register as very likely to enter the country and is expected to cause significant economic impact to affected crops, scoring the maximum score on the ‘value at risk’ scale.

Dr Andy Evans, a pest management expert at SRUC, said: “From a Scottish perspective, it was the soft fruit industry that raised concerns about this insect, first for the damage it can cause to crops, but also the impact it could have on exports.
description: Traps have been set for an Asian stink bug amid fears it has come to the UK and could decimate our fruit crops.
